task: Concatenate all .MF4 files in the folder C:\Users\ADMIN\Downloads\ev-data-pack-v10\ev-data-pack-v10\electric_cars\log_files\Tesla Model 3\LOG\3F78A21D\00000001. Save the concatenated file as Tesla_Model_3_3F78A21D.mf4 in the same folder. GUI instructions: To load all MF4 files:Option 1: Go to File → Open Folder, then enter the path of the desired folder and select it to automatically load all MF4 files within that folder.Option 2: Go to File → Open, then enter the path of the desired folder, select any .MF4 file, press Ctrl + A to highlight all files in the folder, and then press Enter to load them all.

plan.reasoning: Activate the asammdf window so subsequent queries and interactions target the correct application.
Capture the current UI state to discover menus and controls (required before the next click).
Open the Mode menu so we can switch to Batch processing (Batch mode is required for concatenation).
Discover the 'Batch processing' menu item after opening the Mode menu.
Switch application to Batch processing mode which enables concatenation of multiple files.
Capture the Batch processing view to locate the 'Add files' button and other batch controls.
Verify current UI state (ensure menus and batch view are active) and obtain fresh element references before interacting with File menu.
Open the File menu since the 'Add files' button is not present; File → Open is a KB-supported alternative to load multiple MF4 files in Batch processing mode.
Capture the UI after opening the File menu so we can locate the 'Open' menu item or any file-dialog trigger exposed by the menu.
Select File → Open to open a file selection dialog that can load multiple .MF4 files into the Batch processing list (per KB guidance).
Inspect the file open dialog to find the 'File name' edit control and visible file entries so we can navigate to the target folder and select files.
Focus the 'File name' edit in the file dialog so we can type the folder path directly (faster and reliable for deep folders).
Enter the exact folder path (single backslashes at runtime; escaped in JSON) and press Enter to navigate the file dialog to the folder containing the .MF4 files.
Give the file dialog a moment to update the file list after navigation.
Refresh UI state to discover visible .MF4 file entries now that the dialog is pointing at the target folder.
Select any single visible .MF4 file in the folder as an anchor for multi-selection (using wildcard to match one of the MF4 file entries discovered).
Select all files in the folder (Ctrl+A) so every .MF4 will be loaded into the Batch processing list per the user's intended approach.
Confirm the selection in the file dialog which will load all selected .MF4 files into the application's Batch processing list.
Capture the Batch processing UI now populated with the selected files so we can choose the Concatenate operation and set the output.
Ensure the Concatenate operation/tab is selected (a Concatenate tab and button exist in the current UI state) so the batch will merge files rather than perform another operation.
Allow the UI to switch to the Concatenate configuration view and expose any output controls or buttons.
Invoke the Concatenate action control which, in this UI, opens the save dialog or starts the prompt to set the output file location/name.
Inspect the save dialog (or output filename control) that appears after invoking Concatenate to find the 'File name' edit where we will type the output filename.
Focus the output 'File name' edit in the save dialog so we can enter the desired concatenated filename and path.

Enter the full output path and filename (single backslashes at runtime; escaped in JSON) to save the concatenated MF4 file in the same folder with the requested name, then confirm the save to start the concatenation process.
Verify that the concatenation process has started or completed and that the new file appears in the folder or the application shows a finished/batch-complete state.

[RECOVERY PLAN]
Completed 6 steps successfully.
Recovery reasoning: DETAILED EXPLANATION REQUIRED:
1. ASSUMPTION vs REALITY: The original plan assumed an 'Add files' button existed in the Batch processing UI. The captured state shows no 'Add files' element, but does show a File menu and an 'Open' menu item plus active Concatenate tab/button. Therefore the assumption about the 'Add files' control was incorrect; however, the File→Open path is available.

2. INTENT: The failed action intended to open a file-selection dialog to load all .MF4 files into Batch processing so they could be concatenated into a single output MF4 file saved in the same folder.

3. ALTERNATIVE SOLUTION: Use File → Open (documented in the KB) to load multiple files while in Batch processing mode. Specifically: open File menu, choose Open, navigate to the target folder using the file dialog's 'File name' edit, select one file then Ctrl+A to multi-select all .MF4 files, confirm to load them into Batch processing. Then select the Concatenate operation/tab and trigger the Concatenate action which opens a save dialog where the output path/name can be specified.

4. KB GUIDANCE: The knowledge base explicitly lists File → Open as a method to load multiple MDF/MF4 files and confirms Batch processing supports multiple-file selection. It also documents switching to Batch processing mode (already done). The recovery follows that KB workflow but uses the actual File menu elements visible in the current state.

5. PENDING PLAN ADAPTATION: Kept steps that are valid: navigating the file dialog by typing the folder path, using Ctrl+A to select all files, confirming selection, choosing the Concatenate operation, and entering the output filename. Modified steps: replaced the missing 'Add files' button click with File → Open menu interactions. Added explicit State-Tool calls after each menu/dialog change to ensure element references are fresh and valid. Discarded any reliance on a non-existent 'Add files' control.

6. SUCCESS RATIONALE: This plan uses only elements present in the captured UI (File menu, Open, Concatenate tab/button, file dialog 'File name' edit) and follows KB-approved workflows. By typing the folder path into the file dialog and using Ctrl+A, all .MF4 files will be reliably selected and loaded into Batch processing. Invoking the Concatenate action opens the save dialog so we can specify the exact output filename (Tesla_Model_3_3F78A21D.mf4) in the same folder, then start the concatenation. Frequent State-Tool calls ensure each step acts on currently visible elements, avoiding the previous failure caused by assuming a missing control.
Total steps in merged plan: 26
